articles.title: Nature's News & Views roundup of 2025
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 19 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04065-6From astrophysics to genetics, climate change to materials science — the News & Views team talk about some of their science highlights of 2025.
articles.content:
From astrophysics to genetics, climate change to materials science — the News & Views team talk about some of their science highlights of 2025.

Download Nature's News & Views roundup of 2025

Nature: Asteroids, antibiotics and ants: a year of remarkable science

In this episode:

1:58 Evidence of ancient brine on an asteroid

Samples taken from the asteroid Bennu by NASA's OSIRIS-REx spacecraft suggest the parent body it originated from is likely to have contained salty, subsurface water. This finding provides insights into the chemistry of the early Solar System, and suggests that brines might have been an important place where pre-biotic molecules were formed.

News & Views: Asteroid Bennu contains salts from ancient brine

Nature Podcast: Asteroid Bennu contains building blocks of life

08:01 How gene expression doesn't always reflect a cell's function

Cells are often grouped into categories according to the RNA molecules they produce. However a study of zebrafish (Danio rerio) brains revealed that cells can be functionally diverse even if they appear molecularly similar. This finding adds more nuance to how a cell's ‘type’ is ultimately defined.

News & Views: Does a cell’s gene expression always reflect its function?

12:01 The disproportionate mortality risks of extreme rainfall

An assessment of death rates in India’s coastal megacity of Mumbai revealed that the impact of extreme rainfall events will be highest for women, young children and residents of informal settlements. This situation is likely to become more pronounced as a result of climate change.

News & Views: Extreme rainfall poses the biggest risk to Mumbai’s most vulnerable people

14:46 An AI-designed underwater glue

Inspired by animals like barnacles and aided by machine learning, researchers have developed a super-sticky compound that works as an underwater adhesive. To demonstrate its properties, researchers applied it to a rubber duck, which stuck firmly to a rock on a beach despite being battered by the sea.

News & Views: AI learns from nature to design super-adhesive gels that work underwater

Nature Podcast: Underwater glue shows its sticking power in rubber duck test

These represent meaningful breakthroughs with broad scientific and societal relevance, especially the AI-designed adhesive which has practical applications and the climate risk findings which inform public health and policy.
articles.personality_title: 2025's top science stories: from ancient space water to sticky underwater glue
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In 2025, scientists made several important discoveries in different fields like space, biology, climate, and technology. These advances help us understand the world and solve real problems.

**What happened** – NASA's OSIRIS-REx mission found salty water from long ago inside an asteroid called Bennu. Researchers studying zebrafish brains discovered that cells can act differently even if they look the same on a genetic level. In Mumbai, a study showed that extreme rainstorms hurt women, children, and people living in poor areas the most. Scientists also used artificial intelligence (AI) to create a super-strong glue that works underwater, tested by sticking a rubber duck to a rock.

**Impact** – The salty water on Bennu tells us about how life’s building blocks might have started in space. Understanding cell differences helps improve medical research. Knowing who is most at risk from heavy rains can guide better safety plans. The AI-made underwater glue could help fix things in wet places, like underwater repairs or medicine.

**What's next step** – Scientists will keep studying Bennu and other space rocks to learn more about early life. Cell research will grow to better define how cells work. Climate studies will push for actions to protect vulnerable people from extreme weather. The new glue might be improved and used in real-life underwater projects.

**One-sentence takeaway** – In 2025, science brought new insights from ancient space water to AI-made underwater glue, offering fresh knowledge and useful tools for the future.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les grandes découvertes scientifiques de 2025 : de l’eau ancienne dans l’espace à la colle sous-marine
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En 2025, des scientifiques ont fait plusieurs découvertes importantes dans des domaines comme l’espace, la biologie, le climat et la technologie. Ces avancées nous aident à mieux comprendre le monde et à résoudre des problèmes concrets.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – La mission OSIRIS-REx de la NASA a trouvé de l’eau salée très ancienne dans un astéroïde appelé Bennu. Des chercheurs étudiant le cerveau du poisson-zèbre ont découvert que des cellules peuvent agir différemment même si elles semblent identiques génétiquement. À Mumbai, une étude a montré que les fortes pluies touchent surtout les femmes, les enfants et les habitants des quartiers pauvres. Des scientifiques ont aussi utilisé l’intelligence artificielle (IA) pour créer une colle très forte qui fonctionne sous l’eau, testée en collant un canard en caoutchouc sur un rocher.

**Impact** – L’eau salée sur Bennu nous parle de la façon dont les éléments de la vie ont pu commencer dans l’espace. Comprendre les différences entre cellules aide la recherche médicale. Savoir qui est le plus en danger lors de fortes pluies permet de mieux protéger ces personnes. La colle sous-marine créée par l’IA pourrait servir à réparer des objets dans l’eau ou en médecine.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques continueront d’étudier Bennu et d’autres roches spatiales pour en apprendre plus sur l’origine de la vie. La recherche sur les cellules progressera pour mieux comprendre leur fonctionnement. Les études climatiques encourageront des mesures pour protéger les populations vulnérables. La nouvelle colle pourrait être améliorée et utilisée dans des projets sous-marins réels.

**En une phrase** – En 2025, la science a apporté de nouvelles découvertes, de l’eau ancienne dans l’espace à une colle sous-marine créée par IA, offrant des connaissances et des outils utiles pour l’avenir.
articles.personality_title_es: Las principales historias científicas de 2025: del agua antigua en el espacio al pegamento bajo el agua
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En 2025, los científicos hicieron varios descubrimientos importantes en campos como el espacio, la biología, el clima y la tecnología. Estos avances nos ayudan a entender mejor el mundo y a resolver problemas reales.

**Qué pasó** – La misión OSIRIS-REx de la NASA encontró agua salada muy antigua dentro de un asteroide llamado Bennu. Investigadores que estudiaron cerebros de peces cebra descubrieron que las células pueden comportarse diferente aunque se vean iguales genéticamente. En Mumbai, un estudio mostró que las lluvias fuertes afectan más a mujeres, niños y personas que viven en zonas pobres. Científicos usaron inteligencia artificial (IA) para crear un pegamento súper fuerte que funciona bajo el agua, probado pegando un pato de goma a una roca.

Saber quiénes son los más afectados por las lluvias fuertes permite proteger mejor a esas personas. El pegamento creado con IA podría ayudar a reparar cosas en lugares mojados, como bajo el agua o en medicina.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos seguirán estudiando a Bennu y otras rocas espaciales para aprender más sobre el origen de la vida. La investigación celular avanzará para entender mejor cómo funcionan las células. Los estudios climáticos impulsarán acciones para proteger a las personas vulnerables. El nuevo pegamento podría mejorarse y usarse en proyectos reales bajo el agua.

**Resumen en una frase** – En 2025, la ciencia trajo nuevas ideas desde el agua antigua en el espacio hasta un pegamento bajo el agua diseñado por IA, ofreciendo conocimiento y herramientas útiles para el futuro.

articles.title: Quantum computers turned out to be more useful than expected in 2025
articles.summary: Rapid advances in the kind of problems that quantum computers can tackle suggest that they are closer than ever to becoming useful tools of scientific discovery
articles.content:
Rapid advances in the kind of problems that quantum computers can tackle suggest that they are closer than ever to becoming useful tools of scientific discovery

Quantum computers could help us understand how quantum objects behave Galina Nelyubova/Unsplash

For the past year, I kept bringing the same story to my editor: quantum computers are on the edge of becoming useful for scientific discovery.

Of course, that has always been the goal. The idea of using quantum computers to better understand our universe is part of their origin story, and it even featured in a 1981 speech by Richard Feynman. Contemplating the best way to simulate nature, he wrote: “We can give up on our rule about what the computer was, we can say: Let the computer itself be built of quantum mechanical elements which obey quantum mechanical laws.”

Today, Feynman’s vision has been realised by Google, IBM and dozens more companies and academic teams. Their devices are now being used to simulate reality at the quantum level – and here are some highlights.

For me, this year’s quantum developments started with two studies that landed on my desk in June, dealing with high-energy particle physics. Two separate research teams had used two very different quantum computers to simulate the behaviours of pairs of particles in quantum fields. One used Google’s Sycamore chip, made from tiny superconducting circuits controlled with microwaves, and the other used a chip produced by quantum computing company QuEra, based on extremely cold atoms controlled with lasers and electromagnetic forces.

Quantum fields encode how a force, such as the electromagnetic force, would act on a particle at any position in the universe. They also have local structure that dictates the behaviours you should see if you zoom in on any particle. Such fields are hard to simulate in the case of particle dynamics – when the particle is doing something over time and you want to make something like a movie of it. For two very simplified versions of quantum fields that show up in the standard model of particle physics, the two quantum computers tackled this exact task.

Subscriber-only newsletter Sign up to Lost in Space-Time Untangle mind-bending physics, maths and the weirdness of reality with our monthly, special-guest-written newsletter. Sign up to newsletter

Jad Halimeh at the University of Munich, who works in the field but hadn’t been involved with either experiment, even told me that a more muscular version of these experiments, simulating more complex fields on larger quantum computers, could eventually help us understand what particles do inside particle colliders.

Three months later, I was on the phone with two other teams of researchers, again discussing those same two types of quantum computers, which had now been put in service of condensed matter physics. Condensed matter physics is dear to my heart because I studied it in graduate school, but its impact extends far beyond this columnist’s proclivities. It has been particularly critical for the development of the semiconductor technologies that underlie everyday devices such as smart phones.

In September, researchers at Harvard University and the Technical University of Munich in Germany used quantum computers to simulate two exotic phases of matter that had been predicted in theory but eluded more traditional experiments. The quantum computers proved adept at predicting the properties of these strange materials, something that growing and probing crystals in the lab has so far failed to accomplish.

October brought the prospect of a practical use for a new superconducting quantum computer from Google, called Willow. The firm’s researchers and their colleagues used Willow to run an algorithm that can be used to interpret data from nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, which is a commonly used technique for studying molecules in biochemical research.

Though the team’s demonstration with real NMR data didn’t do anything that a traditional computer could not, the mathematics of the algorithm promises to one day exceed the capabilities of classical machines, allowing researchers to learn unprecedented details about molecules. How quickly this bears out depends on the pace at which quantum computing hardware improves.

A month later, a third kind of quantum computer entered the conversation. A company called Quantinuum showed that their Helios-1 quantum computer made from trapped ions can run simulations of a mathematical model for perfect electrical conductivity, or superconductivity. Because they conduct electricity without any losses, superconductors may open the door for extremely efficient electronics or even make the electrical grid more sustainable. However, all known superconductors work only under high pressure or extremely low temperature, which makes them impractical. A mathematical model that reveals exactly why some materials superconduct would be a crucial stepping stone towards building useful superconductors.

Helios-1 simulated what Henrik Dryer, a researcher at Quantinuum, told me is possibly the most important such model; one that has held physicists’ attention since the 1960s. And while this specific simulation didn’t offer any radical new insight into superconductivity, it did announce quantum computers as valuable players in physicists’ long-running quest to understand them better.

Just a week later, I found myself on a call with Sabrina Maniscalco from the quantum algorithms firm Algorithmiq, discussing metamaterials. These are materials whose microscopic details can be engineered to have special properties that naturally occurring materials don’t have. They can also be tailor-made for some specific purposes, from rudimentary invisibility cloaks to chemical ingredients that can accelerate reactions.

Metamaterials are also something that I had dabbled in as a graduate student, and Maniscalco’s team worked out how to simulate one using an IBM quantum computer made from superconducting circuits. Specifically, they could track how a metamaterial scrambles information, including in regimes where a more conventional computer may struggle. Though this may sound like a rather abstract setup, Maniscalco told me that it could advance research into chemical catalysts as well as solid state batteries and certain devices that convert light to electricity.

As if particle physics, novel phases of matter, molecular investigations, superconductors and metamaterials weren’t enough, while I was outlining this column I got a tip about a study where a team of researchers at the University of Maryland in the US and the University of Waterloo, Canada, used a trapped ion quantum computer to determine how particles bound by the strong nuclear force behave at different temperatures and densities. Some of this behaviour is thought to take place inside neutron stars, which are poorly understood cosmic objects, and also to have occurred in the early universe.

While the team’s quantum calculation involved approximations that don’t quite match the most realistic models of the strong force, the study makes the case for yet another field of physics where quantum computers are up-and-coming as discovery machines.

Certainly, this abundance of examples also comes with an abundance of caveats and question marks. Most mathematical models that have been simulated on quantum hardware require some number of simplifications and approximations compared with the most realistic ones, most quantum computers are still so error-prone as to require the results of their computations to be post-processed to mitigate or remove those errors, and the issue of benchmarking quantum computers’ results against what the best conventional computers can do remains thorny.

Put simply, traditional computing and simulation methods are another area where progress has been fast and encouraging, placing classical and quantum computer researchers into a dynamic back-and-forth where yesterday’s most complex or fastest computation inevitably becomes tomorrow’s runner-up. In the past month, IBM even partnered with several other companies to launch a publicly available “quantum advantage tracker”, which will eventually become a leaderboard showing where quantum computers are pulling ahead of their conventional counterparts – or not.

But even if quantum computers don’t make it to the top of that list any time soon, this past year of reporting still shifted my priors towards excitement and anticipation. That’s because these experiments effectively move quantum computers from being the subject of scientific study to being tools for doing science in a way that was impossible just a few years ago.

At the start of this year, I expected to be mostly writing about benchmarking experiments, where quantum computers run protocols that show off their quantumness rather than solve any useful problems. Such computations often serve to highlight just how different quantum computers are from conventional computers, and they can underline their potential to do radically new things. But the road from there to a useful calculation for a working physicist seemed long and not at all obvious. Now, albeit with caution, I think that road may be shorter than I expected. I’m sure more quantum surprises will await me in 2026.

articles.personality_title: Quantum computers make real progress in solving scientific puzzles in 2025
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Quantum computers are special machines designed to solve problems that normal computers find very hard. Scientists have hoped for decades that these machines could help us understand the universe in new ways, but until recently, their practical use was limited.

**What happened** – In 2025, researchers used different kinds of quantum computers to study important scientific questions. These included simulating particles in physics, exploring new types of materials, and examining molecules for biochemical studies. Companies like Google, IBM, QuEra, and Quantinuum built quantum computers that worked on real scientific problems, showing they can do useful work beyond just testing their technology.

**Impact** – These advances are important because they show quantum computers are moving from theory to practice. For example, quantum computers simulated particle behaviors that could help us understand what happens inside particle accelerators. They also predicted properties of materials that are hard to study with regular experiments. In other cases, they helped model superconductors, which could lead to more efficient electronics and power systems. This means quantum computers could speed up discoveries in physics, chemistry, and materials science.

**What's next step** – Researchers will continue improving quantum computers to handle more complex problems with fewer errors. New tools, like a “quantum advantage tracker” launched by IBM and partners, will help show when quantum computers outperform traditional ones. As hardware and software get better, quantum computers may soon become everyday tools for scientists exploring the smallest parts of nature.

**One-sentence takeaway** – In 2025, quantum computers took important steps toward becoming practical tools that help scientists solve complex problems in physics, chemistry, and materials science.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les ordinateurs quantiques franchissent une étape clé dans la recherche scientifique en 2025
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les ordinateurs quantiques sont des machines spéciales conçues pour résoudre des problèmes très difficiles pour les ordinateurs classiques. Depuis des décennies, les scientifiques espèrent que ces machines aideront à mieux comprendre l’univers, mais leur usage pratique restait limité.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En 2025, des chercheurs ont utilisé différents types d’ordinateurs quantiques pour étudier des questions scientifiques importantes. Ils ont simulé des particules en physique, exploré de nouveaux matériaux et examiné des molécules pour la recherche biochimique. Des entreprises comme Google, IBM, QuEra et Quantinuum ont construit des ordinateurs quantiques capables de résoudre de vrais problèmes scientifiques, montrant qu’ils sont utiles au-delà des tests technologiques.

**Impact** – Ces progrès montrent que les ordinateurs quantiques passent de la théorie à la pratique. Par exemple, ils ont simulé le comportement des particules, ce qui pourrait aider à comprendre ce qui se passe dans les accélérateurs de particules. Ils ont aussi prédit des propriétés de matériaux difficiles à étudier autrement. Ils ont modélisé des supraconducteurs, pouvant rendre l’électronique et les réseaux électriques plus efficaces. Cela signifie que les ordinateurs quantiques pourraient accélérer les découvertes en physique, chimie et science des matériaux.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs vont continuer à améliorer les ordinateurs quantiques pour résoudre des problèmes plus complexes avec moins d’erreurs. Des outils comme un « suivi de l’avantage quantique » lancé par IBM aideront à mesurer quand ces ordinateurs surpassent les classiques. Avec de meilleurs matériels et logiciels, les ordinateurs quantiques pourraient bientôt devenir des outils courants pour les scientifiques.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – En 2025, les ordinateurs quantiques ont fait des progrès importants pour devenir des outils pratiques aidant les scientifiques à résoudre des problèmes complexes en physique, chimie et science des matériaux.
articles.personality_title_es: Los ordenadores cuánticos avanzan en 2025 para resolver problemas científicos reales
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los ordenadores cuánticos son máquinas especiales diseñadas para resolver problemas que los ordenadores normales no pueden manejar fácilmente. Durante décadas, los científicos han esperado que estas máquinas ayuden a entender mejor el universo, pero hasta hace poco su uso práctico era limitado.

**Qué pasó** – En 2025, investigadores usaron diferentes tipos de ordenadores cuánticos para estudiar preguntas importantes en la ciencia. Simularon partículas en física, exploraron nuevos materiales y analizaron moléculas para investigaciones bioquímicas. Empresas como Google, IBM, QuEra y Quantinuum construyeron ordenadores cuánticos que trabajaron en problemas científicos reales, demostrando que pueden ser útiles más allá de pruebas tecnológicas.

**Impacto** – Estos avances son importantes porque muestran que los ordenadores cuánticos están pasando de la teoría a la práctica. Por ejemplo, simularon el comportamiento de partículas, lo que podría ayudar a entender lo que ocurre en aceleradores de partículas. También predijeron propiedades de materiales difíciles de estudiar con métodos tradicionales. Modelaron superconductores, que podrían hacer la electrónica y las redes eléctricas más eficientes. Esto significa que los ordenadores cuánticos podrían acelerar descubrimientos en física, química y ciencia de materiales.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores seguirán mejorando los ordenadores cuánticos para manejar problemas más complejos con menos errores. Herramientas como un “rastreador de ventaja cuántica” lanzado por IBM ayudarán a mostrar cuándo los ordenadores cuánticos superan a los clásicos. A medida que el hardware y software mejoren, estos ordenadores podrían convertirse pronto en herramientas habituales para los científicos.

**Conclusión en una frase** – En 2025, los ordenadores cuánticos dieron pasos importantes para convertirse en herramientas prácticas que ayudan a científicos a resolver problemas complejos en física, química y ciencia de materiales.
